channel.title: Introduction on Secure I/O
channel.description: Recent content in Introduction on Secure I/O

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Secure I/O is an open-source project that provides provable secure authenticated encryption for data streams. It has been developed because many widely used solutions for data encryption are not well-suited for streaming or cannot preserve important security guarantees. Take a look at the FAQ to learn more about the limitations of classical encryption schemes.

item.title: FAQ
item.description: What does “provable secure” mean? TL;DR: The authenticated encryption scheme used by Secure I/O is secure if the underlying AEAD, e.g. AES-GCM, is secure. In modern cryptography people often try to proof the security of algorithms or protocols. The advantage of a security proof is that you know - for sure - that the scheme guarantees certain security properties. However, a security proof does neither mean that the scheme cannot be broken at all nor that it can be applied out of context.
